image.altText: Michele Bullock

items.synopsis: Reserve Bank of Australia governor Michele Bullock says the central bank "will not hesitate" to increase the cash rate over fears inflation could take longer to return to target than its current "late 2025" forecast.

title.children: RBA 'will not hesitate' to increase rates if inflation takes longer to return to target than forecast, Bullock warns

image.altText: Bill Shorten at a press conference

items.synopsis: The NDIS regulator commissions an independent inquiry after an ABC investigation found providers had unlawfully restrained children with disabilities in a manner which amounted to a breach of human rights.

title.children: NDIS providers banned and fined $1m, independent review ordered after ABC investigation

image.altText: Riverlea

items.synopsis: The ancestral remains of at least 27 people will be re-buried at a location near the $3 billion Riverlea development in Adelaide's north where they were found earlier this year.

title.children: Aboriginal elders make 'difficult' decision to relocate ancestral remains found at housing development

image.altText: A green energy drink can seen from above its pull tab

items.synopsis: Students preparing for exams across Australia are being advised to carefully manage their intake of caffeine, after a pre-exam crackdown by health authorities in one state found energy drinks being sold with almost twice the permissible amount.

title.children: Exam cram warning as one energy drink found to contain 300mg of caffeine per can

image.altText: An elderly woman with short dark hair speaks in front of a crowd of journalists' microphones.

items.synopsis: Yocheved Lifshitz, an 85-year-old grandmother taken hostage by Hamas on October 7, has told reporters in Tel Aviv she "went through hell".

title.children: 'They went berserk': Freed Israeli hostage speaks out about her Hamas ordeal

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We are bringing you more comments from Yocheved Lifshitz, one of the women who was kidnapped by Hamas on October 7 and freed earlier today. You can see a video of part of her statement in our last post. The 85-year-old spoke to the media in Tel Aviv about what conditions were like in Gaza, after she was taken from her kibbutz in Israel on the back of a motorbike. "[We] walked for a few kilometres on the wet grounds. There are a huge, huge network of tunnels underneath. It looks like a spider web," Ms Lifshitz said, according to her daughter who was translating. "We reached a big hole where some 25 kidnapped were concentrated." She said a lot of women had been taken hostage, and a doctor came to check on the hostages every two or three days. "They were gentle with us, our needs were supplied, they were prepared for this, they were prepared for a very long time, including the needs of the women," she said, according to a different translator.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Freed hostage describes walking through 'spider web' of tunnels under Gaza

children.content: We are bringing you more comments from
Yocheved Lifshitz
, one of the women who was kidnapped by Hamas on October 7 and freed earlier today.
You can see
a video of part of her statement in our last post
The 85-year-old spoke to the media in
Tel Aviv
about what conditions were like in
Gaza
, after she was taken from her kibbutz in Israel on the back of a motorbike.

"[We] walked for a few kilometres on the wet grounds. There are a huge, huge network of tunnels underneath. It looks like a spider web," Ms Lifshitz said, according to her daughter who was translating.
"We reached a big hole where some 25 kidnapped were concentrated."
She said a lot of women had been taken hostage, and a doctor came to check on the hostages every two or three days.

"They were gentle with us, our needs were supplied, they were prepared for this, they were prepared for a very long time, including the needs of the women," she said, according to a different translator.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Middle East Correspondent Allyson Horn here – the Israeli Army has just sent out a notice to residents of Gaza, asking for their help to provide information on the location of hostages. The notice reads: “If your will is to live in peace and to have a better future for your children, do the humanitarian deed immediately and share verified and valuable information about hostages being held in your area. "The Israeli military assures you that it will invest maximum effort in providing security for you and your home, and you will receive a financial reward. We guarantee you complete confidentiality.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF asking Gazans for help to locate hostages

children.content: Middle East Correspondent
Allyson Horn
here – the
Israeli Army
has just sent out a notice to residents of Gaza, asking for their help to provide information on the location of hostages.
The notice reads:

“If your will is to live in peace and to have a better future for your children, do the humanitarian deed immediately and share verified and valuable information about hostages being held in your area.
"The Israeli military assures you that it will invest maximum effort in providing security for you and your home, and you will receive a financial reward.
We guarantee you complete confidentiality.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yocheved Lifshitz, an Israeli woman who was taken hostage by Hamas on October 7 and released earlier today, has spoken publicly about her ordeal. Speaking to reporters outside Ichilov hospital in Tel Aviv, where she was taken after being freed, she said that she went "through hell". "They went berserk in our kibbutz, put me on a motorcycle on the side and drove through the fields," she said, according to a TV translator. "They blew up the [kibbutz's] fence … masses stormed our homes, hit people they kidnapped, many did not care about kidnapping elderly and children. "It was extremely painful."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Video: 85yo Israeli hostage talks about being kidnapped on motorbike

children.content: Yocheved Lifshitz
, an Israeli woman who was taken hostage by Hamas on October 7 and released earlier today, has spoken publicly about her ordeal.
Speaking to reporters outside Ichilov hospital in Tel Aviv, where she was taken after being freed, she said that she went "through hell".
"They went berserk in our kibbutz, put me on a motorcycle on the side and drove through the fields," she said, according to a TV translator.
"They blew up the [kibbutz's] fence … masses stormed our homes, hit people they kidnapped, many did not care about kidnapping elderly and children.
"It was extremely painful."

image.altText: Malcolm McLeod, Sam Wyatt and Jason Bilney

items.synopsis: Whyalla residents are optimistic — but increasingly impatient — about progress on a hydrogen plant and storage facility planned for their town, following the state government's announcement of its preferred partners for the project.

title.children: Regional SA residents want 'less talk and more action' over proposed $600m hydrogen project

image.altText: A mother and son stand with a suitcase under a "Departures" sign in an airport.

items.synopsis: Ibrahim fears for each day that passes with his mother still trapped in Gaza. He says the Australian government has helped to repatriate hundreds from Israel, but that he and others with family trapped in Gaza have not seen the same support.

title.children: 'Living a lie': Family of Australian trapped in Gaza say they are helpless and frustrated at Australia's response

image.altText: Power plant smoke stack

items.synopsis: Almost half of the world's power will come from "clean" technologies such as wind, solar and nuclear by 2030, but the International Energy Agency says it "may not be enough" to limit global warming.

title.children: Fossil fuels to peak within the decade, according to International Energy Agency

image.altText: Smoke blows towards a city area

items.synopsis: The Arson Squad is investigating a bushfire burning in Kings Park in central Perth, with police saying it appears the fire had "multiple ignition points".

title.children: 'I thought I was going to burn': Kings Park closed to public as firefighters battle 'suspicious' bushfire

image.altText: A woman with short orange hair smiles, she wears a shirt with squid reading 'squid squad' she holds her belly.

items.synopsis: Kimberlee Murdoch, a gestational surrogate for a gay couple living hundreds of kilometres away, is "doing it for the dads" trying to start their own family.

title.children: Surrogate mum 'purely baking for friends' as she helps another couple create their own family

image.altText: Bushfire burning at night

items.synopsis: Flames as high as 10 metres are being reported as two dangerous bushfires burn in southern Queensland.

title.children: Homes lost as 10m tall flames engulf bushland in southern Queensland

image.altText: Burrungkuy (Nourlangie) viewed from the Kunwarddewardde lookout in Kakadu National Park. 2

items.synopsis: A land and air search is underway for a woman police believe has been missing in Kakadu National Park for almost a week.

title.children: Search underway for woman missing in Kakadu National Park for almost a week

image.altText: A cartoon image of Jacinta Allan's face.

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan is among those criticising a nude depiction of her published in the Herald Sun, describing it as "sexualised imagery" — but the cartoonist has defended his work as "fair political comment".

title.children: Herald Sun cartoonist defends nude catwalk depiction of Premier Jacinta Allan

image.altText: A memorial on Deans Avenue in Christchurch for the shooting victims looks over one of the scenes of the massacre.

items.synopsis: The largest coronial inquest New Zealand has ever held starts today to look into the emergency response to the Christchurch terror attacks at two mosques in 2019.

title.children: A coronial inquest into the Christchurch attack will look at what NZ 'may learn from this atrocity'

image.altText: Police in uniform line the forecourt steps of the Sydney Opera House with building in background

items.synopsis: The documents reveal "an urgent threat assessment" was ordered into the NSW government's plan to light up the Opera House in the colours of Israeli flag.

title.children: Plan to light Opera House in Israel colours caused senior police concern over escalating tensions, documents reveal

image.altText: a  old man with white hair

items.synopsis: Mathematician Adam Spencer says the string of lucky wins is a statistical aberration. It comes almost a year to the day a syndicate of 20 Kalgoorlie miners won a $53 million jackpot that saw them each take home about $2.6m.

title.children: 'Staggeringly unlikely': Outback newsagent's six division one lotto winners a statistical phenomenon

image.altText: A lady at the computer

items.synopsis: A line is finally drawn under an Adelaide woman's 12-year legal battle against global tech giant Google after she sued the company twice, mostly unrepresented – and won.

title.children: Adelaide woman receives settlement after 12-year battle with Google

image.altText: Police tape across the front of house that has been destroyed by fire

items.synopsis: A man is fighting for life and a woman is hospitalised with burns after a fire at a house in suburban Adelaide on Monday evening.

title.children: One person fighting for life, another with burns after house destroyed at Royal Park

image.altText: Anthony Albanese stands next to a screen that says "helping Australia seize the AI era".

items.synopsis: Tech giant Microsoft will help Australia build a "cyber shield" as part of a plan to sink billions of dollars into securing and expanding the national digital economy, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese reveals on a trip to the US.

title.children: Albanese, Microsoft reveal tech giant's biggest-ever investment in Australia

image.altText: A person uses a ruler to measure someone's feet.

items.synopsis: An investigation into the business practices of a podiatrist who describes himself as probably the highest-paid practitioner in Australia has exposed some deep failings in the health system that open it up to rorting and privacy breaches.

title.children: 'Unpoliced pots of gold': The questionable business practices in podiatry

image.altText: A satellite image showing buildings and streets in a densely buitl city

items.synopsis: The tiny enclave of Gaza is home to 2.1 million people on the coast of the Mediterranean. Here's how it compares in size to Australia.

title.children: How big is the Gaza Strip? Here's how the tiny enclave compares to Australia and the world

image.altText: A wispy, rainbow coloured cloud stretches across a bright blue sky, surrounded by sparse white clouds.

items.synopsis: A perfect storm of conditions sees a unique weather phenomenon form above a Wheatbelt town, lasting for a few fleeting minutes.

title.children: Rarely seen ephemeral cloud iridescence appears above WA country town

image.altText: A composite image featuring two hidden long dogs

items.synopsis: If you pause the telly at just the right moment and look in just the right spot, you'll see it. Or you could just look up the answers online, but where's the fun in that?

title.children: What are 'long dogs' and why are they driving adult Bluey fans crazy?

image.altText: An image of Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson wearing a brown jacket with a white shirt and a black bowtie.

items.synopsis: A French museum says it is working urgently to fix a waxwork of Dwayne 'The Rock' Johnson.

title.children: The Rock says French wax figure needs 'updating' over skin tone

image.altText: A man in police uniform sits at a desk with a small microphone and nameplate in front of him.

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police is being questioned over why it allowed police from Hong Kong to tour cyber sites in Canberra and Perth, despite concerns of Chinese espionage.

title.children: AFP grilled on why it allowed Hong Kong officers to tour sensitive cyber command

image.altText: A woman in blue jumper and white scarf crouches down with her black dog with white facial hairs.

items.synopsis: The beauty and wonder of the natural world is what keeps scientists like Dana Bergstrom fighting to protect it. She's one of many who say speaking out comes at a cost  but not speaking up can take an even greater personal toll.

title.children: Gagged and grief-stricken, yet defiant: Ecologists and climate scientists reveal devastating culture of suppression

image.altText: A photo of a child in school uniform attached to a fridge.

items.synopsis: Marjorie identified as a woman, but was put in with men in Tasmania's Risdon Prison. Eventually, she refused treatment for an illness and died. Now, her family wants an investigation — saying authorities knew she was at risk of abuse.

title.children: 'They're killing me, mum': Marjorie was in a men's prison for years. Then she died

image.altText: Street in Northern Gaza after explosion, hole in road surprised by debris and rubble

items.synopsis: A family of four, including two children, were in Gaza for the first time in 12 years when Hamas attacked. They say while they're enduring the ongoing destruction, their mental health is "beyond horrible".

title.children: 'We may not live until tomorrow': An Australian family's holiday to Gaza has become a struggle for survival

image.altText: A man sits in rubble on his phone.

items.synopsis: History has shown us that once wars begin, military actions often take on a life of their own. Regardless of when, or if, Israel enters Gaza with its ground forces in the coming days, there will be many surprises ahead, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: If Israel's massive army crosses into Gaza soon, one thing is certain: Things will go wrong

image.altText: A white, modernist, flat-fronted building with "supreme court" in capital letters above a wide entrance.

items.synopsis: Kaspar Hansman, 30, pleaded guilty to 11 charges after carrying out a 'drug-fuelled, revenge-motivated' attack on his ex-girlfriend and her boyfriend in 2021.

title.children: 'Like a horror movie': Man sentenced to decade in prison over meth-fuelled Darwin attacks

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie

items.synopsis: Justice Michael Lee last week ruled the ABC's public interest defence had failed, but rejected Mr Russell's claim for aggravated damages.

title.children: ABC removes defamatory stories and ordered to pay $400k to former commando Heston Russell

image.altText: Bobi the dog sitting on the grass.

items.synopsis: Officials at the Guinness World Records say they are "saddened to learn of the death of Bobi, the world's oldest dog ever."

title.children: World's oldest dog dies in Portugal aged 31

image.altText: A satellite image of a tropical cyclone

items.synopsis: Seven months after being battered by twin cyclones, Vanuatu is bracing for another one as cyclone Lola bears down on the country's second-biggest city.

title.children: Just months after 'evil twin' cyclones, Vanuatu braces for new 'destructive' category 5 cyclone Lola

image.altText: A composite image of a small joey in a pouch, and joey wearing black carbon-graphite prosthetic on its tail.

items.synopsis: A young kangaroo named Cottontail is given a new lease on life, after part of its tail was amputated when its mother was struck by a car in Queensland.

title.children: Amputee joey now hopping with joy thanks to a shoehorn and some innovative thinking
